Culinary Profile & Uses

1. Flavour and Form ‘Tiny Kabu’ offers a surprisingly sweet, nutty, and mild flavour with none of the pungency or bitterness associated with larger turnip varieties. The roots have an incredibly smooth, creamy texture - similar to a crisp apple - and thin, edible skin. The attached greens are tender and mild, resembling delicate mustard greens without the sharpness. The entire plant forms a low, tidy rosette ideal for dense planting.

2. The Dual-Purpose Delicacy This turnip’s greatest virtue is its versatility, with both roots and greens being culinary treasures.

  • Raw and Fresh: The roots are tender and sweet enough to be eaten raw, sliced thin in salads or served with dip like a radish.
  • Glazed or Roasted: Whole or halved, they caramelize beautifully when roasted or glazed with miso or honey, becoming even sweeter and more tender.
  • Quick-Pickled: Their small size and crisp texture make them perfect for quick-pickling, creating a sweet-and-tangy condiment.
  • Sautéed Greens: The greens can be sautéed with garlic as a nutritious side dish, or used raw in salads when very young.

3. The Harvest and Yield ‘Tiny Kabu’ matures with remarkable speed. For the best texture, harvest the roots when they are young and firm, typically at 3-4 cm in diameter. Greens can be harvested lightly throughout growth. Supplied as an RFID seed tape, a single planting provides a dense and uniform yield of 6-10 perfectly formed mini-turnips and a substantial bunch of greens, with roots ready for harvest in just 35-40 days from sowing.
